author: Victor Torres
description:
This weekâ€™s composition challenge. Composed using (virtual) dice to select the scale and the individual notes. Performed with Ableton Live and the Korg Volca Bass, which has a programmable 16 step sequencer. Each step was determined by the dice throw. The first throw determines the scale. I decided to go with the western classical scales. On the other throws, numbers 1 to 7 determine the note played in each of the 16 steps (which you can imagine as 4 counts within each hit of the metronome or 16 equally spaced out positions within one meter) and 8 would be silence. Here are the results:


First Roll: 9 = Ab major scale


Osc 1 Rolls

	4 - Db
	4 - Db
	4 - Db
	5 - Eb

	2 - Bb
	6 - F
	1 - Ab
	4 - Db

	6 - F
	1 - Ab
	8 - Silence
	7 - G

	3 - C
	4 - Db
	3 - C
	1 - Ab

Osc 2 Rolls

	1 - Ab
	1 - Ab
	6 - F
	6 - F

	7 - G
	7 - G
	7 - G
	5 - Eb

	6 - F
	4 - Db
	8 - Silence
	5 - Eb

	8 - Silence
	7 - G
	7 - G
	3 - C

Osc 3 Rolls

	4 - Db
	2 - Bb
	7 - G
	1 - Ab

	1 - Ab
	7 - G
	4 - Db
	8 - Silence

	8 - Silence
	8 - Silence
	2 - Bb
	3 - C

	1 - Ab
	5 - Eb
	7 - G
	6 - F

description: Party Balloons!

comments.comment: This sketch has a great balance of randomness and controll.

Your use of decks is especially effective with the colors. You never (rarely) get the same color twice in a row, and you have a curated palette. You also have some columns of larger circles and some of smaller circles which creates some rhythm, concords, and contrasts.

I see some ways you could improve your code style. Let me know if you would like to book an office hour visit to discuss. Also let me know if you would be willing for me to use this code as an example for refactoring in class.

author: Nikki Makagiansar
description: More Karel Martens-inspired sketches, but typographic. Not too proud of how smelly this code got, but hopefully I'll find a way to refactor this. Had some fun with the `clone()` function and creating paths segment by segment. It'd be cool to try this type treatment out on a poster. Last iteration reminds me of strawberries.

comments.comment: and now i'm listening to The The

Regarding code style, this is pretty well done. There are a few things you _could_ do to clean it more, but I don't think anything _needs_ it. Maybe if this grew into a bigger project you'd want to refactor a bit, but it would probably pay off to wait until that happened so you'd have a better idea of what refactoring would better support that growth.

author: Nikki Makagiansar
description: Group sketch with Sydney and Becky! An attempt at recreating the theme song from Pixar's UP ðŸŽˆðŸŽˆðŸŽˆ
code:
// require https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/tone/13.8.6/Tone.min.js

const synth = new Tone.Synth().toMaster();
Tone.Transport.bpm.value = 200;

const melody = [

  ['F4', '8n'],
  ['A4', '8n'],
  ['F4', '8n'],
  
  ['E4', '2n.'],
  ['rest', '8n'],
  ['F4', '8n'],
  ['A4', '8n'],
  ['E4', '8n'],
  
  ['D4', '4n'],
  ['rest', '8n'],
  ['D4', '8n'],
  ['F4', '8n'],
  ['D4', '8n'],
  
  ['C4', '2n'],
  ['rest', '8n'],
  ['D4', '8n'],
  
  ['A4', '4n'],
  ['G4', '4n'],
  ['rest', '8n'],
  ['D4', '8n'],
  
  ['A4', '4n'],
  ['G4', '4n'],
  ['F4', '4n'],
 
  ['D4', '2n.'],
  
  ['rest', '8n'],
  ['F4', '8n'],
  ['G4', '8n'],
  ['F4', '8n'],
  
  ['E4', '2n.'],
  ['rest', '8n'],
  ['E4', '8n'],
  ['G4', '8n'],
  ['E4', '8n'],
  
  ['C4', '4n'],
  ['C4', '8n'],
  ['E4', '8n'],
  ['C4', '8n'],
  
  ['Bb3', '2n'],
  ['rest', '4n'],
  ['A4', '4n'],
  ['Bb3', '4n'],
  
  ['C4', '4n.'],
  ['D4', '8n'],
  ['E4', '4n'],
  
  
  ['rest', '4n'],
  ['C4', '4n'],
  ['D4', '4n'],
  ['E4', '4n.'],
  
  ['F4', '8n'],
  ['A4', '8n'],
  ['F4', '8n'],
  
  ['E4', '2n.'],

  ['rest', '1m'],
];

window.onmousedown = (e) => {
  // Play the melody!

  let t = Tone.now();

  for (const note of melody) {
    console.log(note);
    if (note[0] !== 'rest') {
      // synth.triggerAttackRelease(note[0], note[1]), t);
      synth.triggerAttackRelease(note[0], Tone.Time(note[1]) - 0.1, t);
    }
    t += Tone.Time(note[1]);
  }
};

console.log('click for music!');

author: Rebecca Greubel
description: I've been wanting to figure out culling, and so was studying the cull functions in the strategy chapter. I noticed that as I added layers of culled points, the first point was the only one that, in every instance, was completely not surrounded (makes sense since the function makes the in the same spot every time). I'm working now on developing this further so that the center point follows your mouse, and keeps the other points away.

I'm first-posting pixels! You might find the `getC()` + `setC()` functions helpful to study or use.

This is adapted from the Color Wars cart by Munro Hoberman. He wrote it for pico-8 in 92 characters!

```
n=128for i=0,4^7do
pset(i%n,i/n,rnd(6)+7)end::_::x=rnd(n)y=rnd(n)circ(x,y,1,pget(x,y))goto _
```

author: Shivanjali Verma
description:
Hi, I have experimented with my own instructions. Self introspection of my thoughts and personality, in the form of computational art! Using various colours and shapes to depict different things, it seems as cluttered as many thoughts with different notions I have in a single day, obviously uncountable. Mind doesn't ever stop thinking, so does the art here unless I meditate and find peace.  I have used very simple shapes here, to begin with and mostly focused on how I can move the objects using different code styles. I will continue to explore more, with thoughts, meditative state of mind and chaos through computational art. I hope to achieve something good in the later stages!

Thank you,
Shivi  :D

author: Victor Torres
description:
Messing with the p5 example for FM Synthesis. The basic concept of this form of electronic sound synthesis is that you produce a sound source called 'carrier', which is then affected by another sound source called 'modulator'. It basically pushes the sound wave of the 'modulator' against the sound wave the 'carrier', creating almost endless variations in texture, pitch and rhythm as the general waveform (displayed in the GUI) changes in degrees of complexity.

I decided to map out the major keys of a piano into the computer keyboard (a/s/d/f/g/h/j/k) to change the pitch of the 'carrier' signal, which was invariable in the P5 example. The parameters of the 'modulator' signal are set by the x and y position of the mouse.

author: Dallas Alberti

comments.comment: Whoah, this is awesome. I could totally see this as a data viz chart in a spread for the New York Times or something!
These are looking good. What are you plotting here?

This is visualizing various stages of a mathematic operation. We generate a list of numbers, then transform that list to fixed mean and SD according to sliders. Then output new list, floor and match numbers to whole integers.  Many lines are being visualized but they are all relative to each other. Trying to imagine the 'behind the scenes' management of terrain generation.

description:

The smaller circle cycles through an array of colors when mouse is clicked.

author: Victor Torres
description: Randomized selection of lines from "Japanese Death Poems: Written by Zen Monks and Haiku Poets on the Verge of Death".
code:
let firstLines = ["the fourth day","now spring has come","on a journey", "oh, I don't care","I long for people","leaves never fall","autum gust","disgusted with the world","man's end","I write, erase, rewrite","what matter if I live on","my one wish","since I was born","and if I do","I die","a last fart:","since time began","the night I understood","how sad...","like dewdrops","surely there's a teahouse","my shame in this world","I wake and find","spitting blood","when I leave","I go back","death poems","my forty-four years"]

let secondLines = ["of the new year","into my world","ill my dreams go wandering","where autumn clounds","then again I loathe them","in vain","I have no further business","I withdraw","a mound of gleaming bones","erase again","a tortoise lives","to another","is to live","I have to die","become a spirit","the evening of the day","are these the leaves of my dream","the dead alone know peace","this is a world of dew","amidst the flowers of the spring equinox","on a lotus leaf","with a view of plum trees","will soon be forgotten","the colored iris","clears up reality","these eyes of flesh","the void where the frost and the snow","are mere delusions","bloom in the last verse"]

let thirdLines = ["what a better way to leave the world?","farewell!","over withered fields.","are drifting to.","end of autum.","from all around bells tolling.","in this world.","into the net.","a flowering and a fading.","and then a poppy blooms.","a hundred times as long.","stuff and nonsense.","in the capital of nonaction.","and so...","the party's over.","the hibiscus blooms.","vainly falling?","life is but melting snow.","I woke up from my sleep.","a journey deathward.","I vanish.","on Death Mountain, too.","springtime journey.","I saw in my dream.","and dream alike.","I wish to see the lotus.","won't bother me.","death is death.","of a chain poem."] 



let firstDisplay = {
    id: 0,
    displayText: "Choose your last words!",
    questions: ["Begin"],
    choices: [1],
    end: false
}

let lineOne = {
    id: 1,
    displayText: "Choose the first line of your poem.",
    questions: firstLines,
    choices: [0,1],
    end: false
}

let lineTwo = {
    id: 2,
    displayText: "Choose the second line of your poem.",
    questions: secondLines,
    choices: [0,1],
    end: false
}

let lineThree = {
    id: 3,
    displayText: "Choose the last line of your poem.",
    questions: thirdLines,
    choices: [0, 1],
    end: false
}

let finalDisplay = {
    id: 4,
    displayText: "",
    questions: ["Try Again."],
    choices: [0],
    end: true
}



let objectsArray = [firstDisplay, lineOne, lineTwo, lineThree, finalDisplay]

author: Victor Torres
description:
Decided to build an interfase with enterable parameters for a text generating tool I made for a personal project a while back.

The basic idea is that you input a code word (or letter) and a reference text. The algorithm then replaces any letter that is not present in the code word/letter with a space (" ").
